comment.author: 27753716@N00
comment._content: This looks a lot like Vita Sackville-West, but she'd be the Hon. Mrs. Nicolson (without the "h"). She married Harold Nicolson in 1913, and would have been 18-24 in the time frame this photo was taken (does that seem right? I'm horrible at guessing ages). Does anyone have any more information on this photo (as in, is it really Vita)?

comment.author: 82345514@N00
comment._content: It does look like her. Probably is her, and whomever labeled the negative spelled it incorrectly.

comment.author: 38450396@N06
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called we are love, and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content:
I just did a quick calculation. There are 40,000 Bain negatives according to the Library of Congress. If they are releasing them at a rate of 40 per week it will take 1,000 weeks to complete the project. With 52 weeks in the year it will take 19.2 years to complete the project. We can round that up to 20 years since most weeks there are less than 40, and for several weeks none were posted. 

The LOC also has a newspaper scanning project that is equally slow paced.  

For a comparison, Google Books started in 2004 and scanned 10 millions books by the end of 2009. That is 2 million books a year, or 40K books a week, if they take of two weeks for vacation, which I am sure they do not.

Anyone else have thoughts on the pace of the project?

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Richard, another problem is that LOC keeps interleaving other batches of photos in here, interrupting the Bain flow. I could survive nicely without the gaudy tourist shots of Ireland, the Farm Administration pix (already famous elsewhere) and the front pages of tabloid newspapers. Last Friday, we were given 48 Bain photos to puzzle out, but we could easily have handled a hundred. If LOC insists on dumping the other stuff onto Flickr, I suggest that they run three or four separate photostreams, so that they can keep the several feeds coming at a steady pace, while those of us who wish to do so can focus on the historically-fascinating Bain archive, and ignore the others.

comment.author: 43895776@N00
comment._content: Is there any information about the photographer?

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: This photograph of Vita at twenty-one may have been taken in 1913 for publicity purposes, when her engagement to Harold Nicolson was announced. They were wed on October 1, 1913, which surely was why Bain distributed copies of the photo to his clients at that time. At the time of her marriage, she was deeply, passionately in love -- with a young woman. As members of Britain's landed gentry, her family qualified as newsworthy. Harold Nicolson was a diplomat, posted to the British legation in Turkey, which was then the center of the Ottoman Empire.

comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: Its also a shame that Google Goggles has been disabled for face searching to preserve privacy on the Internet. Google Googles is the latest iteration of Google's image matching software. I am sure it would match many of these images to already labeled photos of these people from Wikipedia.
